thread.title: Central Catholic boys soccer needs a team response to struggles
thread.title_full: Central Catholic boys soccer needs a team response to struggles

title: Central Catholic boys soccer needs a team response to struggles
text:
Central Catholic’s boys soccer team revealed itself as one of the players in the Eastern Pennsylvania Conference through the first month of the season. 
Now, with the postseason rapidly approaching, how the Vikings respond to hardship will determine their ultimate fate. 
Central Catholic fell 3-0 to Parkland on Tuesday afternoon in Eastern Pennsylvania Conference Skyline Division play. 
The Vikings (9-4-1 overall, 7-4-1 EPC) played an even first half but crumbled during a nine-minute segment in which Byron Derti, Tyler Madeira and Justin Evans scored for the Trojans. 
“We had a bad 10 minutes,” Vikings coach Peter Car said. “That’s going to happen to teams, it doesn’t matter if it’s in this league, another league or a pro league. Everybody goes through ups and downs it’s just: how are you going to react from it?” 
Central Catholic’s reaction on Tuesday didn’t do the trick as the team game plan went out the window once a deficit presented itself, according to Car. 
RAPID RECAP : Parkland boys soccer team charges past Central Catholic in 2nd half 
“They weren’t following the script; they weren’t following the process of ‘How can we get back into this game?’” the coach said. “I think too many guys were doing their own thing out there to get us back in (the game). That’s not going to happen against good teams.” 
After Parkland ’s outburst, the Vikings didn’t muster much to trouble Trojans reserve goalkeeper Matthew Lytle. 
“You have to stay as a team the whole game,” Car said. “We just didn’t do that.” 
The Vikings will need to rebound quickly, after going 0-2-1 in their last three results, in order to secure a spot in the conference tournament. Handling the adversity now can fortify Central Catholic for when challenges arise down the road. 
“We don’t want to be trending down heading into the postseason,” Car said. “The biggest thing for them is to stay positive, keep moving forward and just believe that we’re going to get better from this.”
